moves.1. d4: Black surrendered, and I still dont see why
moves.1... d5 2. c4 e6 3. g3 c5:
I dont like playing aganst this move.
The result is usually balck accepting a weak pawn on d5, in return for taking the initiative.
moves.4. Nf3 Nf6 5. Bg2 Nc6 6. O-O Be7 7. cxd5:
I would have expected 7...,exd5; 8.dxc5;
Black has an isolated center pawn, but he also takes the initiave.
moves.8. Nc3 Nf6: Another move with the same piece, this should give me the lead in development
moves.9. Bf4: Fighting over control of e5, hoping to play Ne5
moves.9... a6 10. Qa4:
This move took me a lot of thought.
After carefull consideration I concluded blacks next move was harmless.
moves.10... Bd7 11. dxc5:
Whites idea is playing Rd1 and Ne5,  combining forces against d7 and c6;
If he can white would also like to keep the c5 pawn, after say 11....,Ne5?!, Qc4;
moves.11... Bxc5 12. Qc4: Moving the Queen ou of harms way
moves.12... Ba7 13. Bd6: Hoping to pin the black king in the center
moves.13... Rc8 14. Qh4 Ne7 15. Ba3:
Better is an immediate Ng5, with some tactical play against blacks kingside.
THis is one reason the white Queen went to h4
moves.15... Bc5: Annihilating the pin, white completely missed this move
moves.16. Bxc5: The only way to continue, but much of whites initiative is gone now
moves.16... Rxc5 17. Ng5 Nf5 18. Qb4: Hoping to pin blacks king yet again
moves.19... Nxe4 20. Nxe4 Rb5 21. Qa3: If black noiw play Qe7, he will be in trouble after g3-g4!
moves.21... Ra5:
White still has a dangerous initiative, but to many pieces have been exchanged.
Black has good odds of equalizing
moves.22. Qd3 O-O 23. Rfd1:
Now back surrendered, saying "I must be blind"
The strange thing is he still can play Rd5.

Then we could have 24.Qxa6, Bb5; 25,Rxd5; Qxd5; 26.Qxb6 whcih threatens Nf6+;

Probably black has to accept losing a pawn, but that should be the worst of it
